title: Letter from Rose to Sara
creator: Rose
description: The HLBS played a major role in tzedakah, performing social services and charitable giving. In addition to supporting the local charities through their dues and fundraising, the HLBS also donated to national organizations, including the Cleveland Jewish Orphan Asylum, Denver hospitals, and the Hebrew Union College in Cincinnati. During the depression they assisted unhoused Jews passing through Topeka. They would provide meals, a place to sleep for a night, and a bus or train ticket to a major city-Kansas City or Denver—which had greater resources to provide assistance.
subject: hbls;letters;tzedakah;kosher food
source: Dr. David Katzman and Sharyn Brooks Katzman
image_alt_text: cream discolored envelope with handwritten note and printed address for Scrinopskie's Loan Office
object_transcript:
RETURN IN 5 DAYS TO
Scrinopskie’s Loan Office
410 Kansas Avenue
Topeka Kansas

Dear Sara,
 The hungry are sure being fed if I counted correctly there are 21 meals. Please send them a check, for arrival.
Rose.

title: The Joy of Jewish Cooking Cookbook
creator: Jewish Community Women
description: In 1969, 19 Jewish women prepared a local cookbook and printed it at the World Company Printers in Lawrence. In their preface, they described the joy felt in sharing these recipes, as well as the difficulties associated with writing down specific directions. Often, their recipes were based on oral lessons, where a mother or grandmother would teach her daughters through verbal direction and practice. Many of the measurements were originally based on gut feeling, rather than exact measurements.
subject: kosher food; cookbook
source: Dr. David Katzman and Sharyn Brooks Katzman
rights: Material produced by the United States Forest Service and is in Public Domain. For more information, please contact University of Idaho Library Special Collections and Archives Department at libspec@uidaho.edu.

subject: hbls
source: Dr. David Katzman and Sharyn Brooks Katzman
image_alt_text: Handwritten note addressed to the Hebrew Ladies Benevolent Society
object_transcript:
Topeka […]by 20/98
To the President and Members of the Ladies’ Heb. Ben. Society:
At a recent meeting of the Board of directors your proposition pertaining to your contemplated Purim festival was duly communicated and after a debate on the subject the following resolutions were offered and adopted. 

A.        That it is the sense of this meeting of Board of directors, that the Lad. Society be requested to change its plan […] […] the festival and make […] […] […] – so as to include the children of the members of either society under 15 years of age to be entitled to participate.

title: Biriruch's Record
creator: Industrial Removal Office
description: Refugee resettlement programs, such as the Industrial Removal Office (IRO), often relied on recent immigrants following the paths of relatives who were already established within local communities. This method of placing immigrants helped to integrate recent refugees into existing community support structures. This record shows how a family might follow a relative to the Midwest. It also highlights the importance of an immigrant’s occupation to their application.

title: Meal Bills Paid by HLBS
creator: Hebrew Ladies Benevolent Society
description: The women in the Hebrew Ladies Benevolent Society (HLBS) arranged charge accounts with restaurants, hotels, and transportation lines. These slips represent meals provided; the restaurants billed the HLBS for payment. Most Jewish Topekan women worked for wages downtown, often in their family businesses, so they were physically present to help provide these daily services. In Topeka, the Scrinopskies facilitated this aid; the Scrinopskie family came to Topeka sponsored by the IRO.
subject: kosher food
source: Dr. David Katzman and Sharyn Brooks Katzman

title: Yiddish Map of the United States
creator: Industrial Removal Office
description: Recent immigrants, especially first-generation refugees, are often forced to navigate foreign spaces in unfamiliar languages. Nearly all of the two-million Jewish immigrants from Eastern Europe (1880-1924) spoke Yiddish. This map from the Industrial Removal Office provides essential information about U.S. states and cities. Immigrant guidebooks would publish similar maps, which were important resources for new Americans making their way across the country.
subject: iro; yiddish
source: Dr. David Katzman and Sharyn Brooks Katzman

title: Industrial Removal Office immigrant agreement form
creator: Industrial Removal Office
subject: iro
source: Dr. David Katzman and Sharyn Brooks Katzman
object_transcript:
Industrial Removal Office, 104 RIVINGTON STREET, 
NEW YORK, Jan 10 1905
Removal No. _______________
I, the undersigned having applied to the Industrial Removal Office for work out of the city and my request being granted, do hereby agree upon my arrival at the city to which I am sent to accept such employment as may be obtained for me by the local Society there and to comply with the rules and instructions of that Society, realizing that I have no claim whatever upon this or any of its co-operative agencies. After being placed at work I promise to depend upon my own energies for the support of myself and family.
Signed __________ 
אינדאסטריאל רימואוואל אפפיס,
104 ריווינגטאן סטריט,
ניוארק, __________ 190
איך דער אונטערצייכענטער, האב אנגעבאטען דער אינדאסטריאל רימואוול אפפיס אז מען זאלל מיך שיקען צו ארבייטען אריס דער סיטי, אונד מיין ביטטע האט מען מיר בעשטעטיגט, איך טהוע מיך היערמיט פערפפליכטען דאס ווען איך אנקאמען איך דער שטאט דאן זאל איך ארבייטען בייא דער ארבייט וועלכע דיעזע סאסייעטי וועט געפינען נעטהיג אונד אויך נאכקאמען אלע רולס אונד אינסטראקשאנס פין דער סאסייעטי, אויך האב איך קיין רעכט צו פערלאנגען עטוואס בייא דער ארבייט דאן טהוע איך מיך פערפפליכטען צו סופּפּארטען מיך אונד מיין לאמיליה.
אונטערשריפט _____ עלים שטרינין______

title: Epstein's Kosher Foods Order Form
creator: Epstein's Kosher Foods
description: In the 1970s, Epstein's-butcher, grocery, bakery—was the last surviving kosher market in the metro Kansas City area, once populated by a score of kosher stores. Epstein's originally opened in the 1930s on 18th Street in Kansas City, before moving south in 1968. Sam Epstein took over the business when his father fell ill in the 1940s. Sam Epstein and his wife Gertrude ran it until the late 1980s. This form enabled Epstein's to order adequate Passover supplies and ensured that families in the surrounding region had proper food access for Passover.
subject: kosher food
source: Dr. David Katzman and Sharyn Brooks Katzman

title: The Spirit Unconsumed Book
creator: Temple Beth Sholom
description: Edited by Joy Cumonow and Fred N. Reiner, this book was published in Topeka by Temple Beth Sholom in 1979. The text showcases the agency of local community members who took action to preserve their own stories. The sponsoring committee interviewed members of the community and collected primary text sources to preserve this history. The result is a rich narrative about the lived experiences that also tells the institutional history of Topeka Jewry.
subject: book
source: Dr. David Katzman and Sharyn Brooks Katzman
